block.p: Weeks This Last
On Week Week List Fiction
Weeks This Last
On Week Week List Fiction
PRIMARY COLORS, by Anonymous. (Random House, $24.) The
progress of a certain Southern governor and his wife on
their way to the White House.
THAT CAMDEN SUMMER, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $23.95.) In
1916, a divorced woman, returning to her Maine hometown with
her three daughters, finds scorn, harassment and romance.
INTENSITY, by Dean Koontz. (Knopf, $25.) On a weekend visit to
a Napa Valley farm, a young woman contends with a serial
killer.
ABSOLUTE POWER, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $22.95.) Political
intrigue, sex and murder in Washington's high circles.
THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Delacorte, $23.95.) A
troubled woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and
their horse from a wrangler in Montana.
FIVE DAYS IN PARIS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A
chance encounter between two Americans at the Ritz changes
their lives forever.
CONTAGION, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $24.95.) A physician seeks
to learn why a deadly epidemic has struck a group of
hospitals and clinics.
8 105 THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.)
An ancient manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into
achieving a fulfilling life. (
deadly bombing in an emporium.
IN THE BEAUTY OF THE LILIES, by John Updike. (Knopf, $25.95.)
Over four generations, a family shifts its allegiance from
religious to cinematic illusions.
THE WEB, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $23.95.) On a
research trip to a Pacific island, Alex Delaware encounters
a series of macabre events.
BEHIND THE LINES, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $23.95.) The
Marine Corps must cope with a bogus general in the
Philippines during World War II.
GUILTY AS SIN, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $21.95.) The ordeals of
an assistant district attorney as she prosecutes a college
professor for kidnapping his neighbor's child.
SHOCK WAVE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Dirk
Pitt contends with a ruthless man whose diamond-mining
operations in Antarctica threaten human life.
THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $25.95.)
Scientists visit a Costa Rican jungle that is the breeding
ground of dinosaurs; a sequel to "Jurassic Park."
Weeks This Last
On Week Week List Nonfiction
RUSH LIMBAUGH IS A BIG FAT IDIOT, by Al Franken. (Delacorte,
$21.95.) A television comedian's comments on the current
political scene.
IT TAKES A VILLAGE, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon &
Schuster, $20.) The First Lady's quest for ways to help
create a better society for children.
HOW COULD YOU DO THAT?! by Laura Schlessinger. (HarperCollins,
$22.) A condemnation of self-indulgent morality, and ways to
overcome it. (
Wohlmuth. (Running Press, $27.50.) The relationships of 36
sets of sisters.
ENTER WHINING, by Fran Drescher. (Regan Books/HarperCollins,
$22.) The memoirs of the star of "The Nanny."
Weeks This Last
On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous
1 145 MEN ARE FROM MARS, WOMEN ARE FROM VENUS, by John Gray.
(HarperCollins, $23.) Improving communication and
relationships between the sexes. (

Rankings reflect sales figures, for the week ending Feb. 17, at 3,985 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger ( ) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders for a book.
And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

ATTICUS, by Ron Hansen. (HarperCollins, $22.) A rich, disturbing novel that explicitly favors simplicity, purity and intelligence; its title character forgives his prodigal son more than most readers would be inclined to forgive.

AT THE STILL POINT: A Memoir, by Carol Buckley. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) Deft, evocative, generous recollections by the youngest of William F. Buckley Jr.'s nine siblings; a lot of her life was hellish, but she seems to have emerged in health.

BIRDSONG, by Sebastian Faulks. (Random House, $25.) A novel (the author's fourth) in which the "hell of the trenches" of World War I is played out in the literal underworld of mine and countermine, and the past recaptured through the decoding of a sapper's diary in the 1970's.

DANCING AFTER HOURS: Stories, by Andre Dubus. (Knopf, $23.) Gracious and graceful short fiction, chiefly about love, that addresses matters much closer to the province of poetry than of the novel; the author's eighth collection.

FOUNDING FATHER: Rediscovering George Washington, by Richard Brookhiser. (Free Press, $25.) A noble and effective effort to comprehend a figure whose almost eerie political intelligence is hidden from us by the self-restraint and impersonality that were counted for virtues when he learned them.

THE LOVE AFFAIR AS A WORK OF ART, by Dan Hofstadter. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A rich and rewarding study of five 19th-century French literary couples and their frustrations as they tried to sustain both life and art in an era that was determined to separate the two realms.

THE MIDDLE HEART, by Bette Bao Lord. (Knopf, $25.) This long-running (about 75 years) novel is a lightly disguised history of China itself; its characters are compelled to renounce loved ones, political beliefs and personal morals to survive. NO INTERMISSIONS: The Life of Agnes de Mille, by Carol Easton. (Little, Brown, $29.95.) Even with de Mille's privileges of birth and talent, the price of her achievements as choreographer, author and lecturer, Ms. Easton tells us, was constant combat (she was skilled at that too).

A STRUGGLE FOR POWER: The American Revolution, by Theodore Draper. (Times Books/Random House, $35.) A deep and original approach to the Revolution as a quarrel over sovereignty, beginning with the French and Indian War of 1763 and Britain's determination to make the Colonies pay for their own protection.

TAKING ON THE WORLD: Joseph and Stewart Alsop -- Guardians of the American Century, by Robert W. Merry. (Viking, $34.95.) A dual biography of the smart, wellborn brothers whose programs and opinions dominated American journalism for the generation after World War II.
A TOUR OF THE CALCULUS, by David Berlinski. (Pantheon, $27.50.) An odd and tantalizing book by a writer who takes immense pleasure in this great mathematical tool, and tries to create it in others.
